millsfield:images_texts:
First Flight of Octave Chanute's
Biplane Glider
July 27, 1896 • Chicago, Illinois, U.S.A.
UsAirmail 210
27
1984
60601

International Tributes to the History of Flisfit
First Fligfit of Octave Chanute's Biplane Glider =
Octave Chanute was a French-born, American edu-
cated civil engineer, renowned as a designer of trussed
railroad bridges. In 1874, he became interested in
aviation and began experimenting with various the-
ories of flight. The result of his work was a biplane
glider that combined the strength of trussed wings
with the aerodynamic stability of a box kite.
Chanute set up a camp on the wind-swept beach
of Lake Michigan, near Chicago. Though in his six-
ties, he personally supervised the first test flight of
his craft, scheduled for July 26, 1896. High winds
forced a postponement until the next day. But, on
July 27, Chanute proved the soundness of his biplane
glider design.
The full-color cachet shows one of Chanute's as-
sociates testing the biplane glider. The truss design
of the wings was borrowed from the engineer's rail-
road bridges. The same principle would later be used
in the Wright Brothers' gliders and power aircraft.
Mint Stamp: The mint stamp on this Cover was issued
by the United States in 1979. It pictures Octave
Chanute (1832-1910), one of the pioneers in aircraft
design, and his 1896 biplane glider.
Postmark: This Cover was postmarked in Chicago,
Illinois, on July 27, 1984, the anniversary of the first
flight-test of Chanute's biplane glider.
© Postal Commemorative Society
properties.sfomuseum:description: Airmail flight cover, part of International Tributes to the History of Flight series by the Postal Commemorative Society; white envelope with full color illustration cachet and inset stamp commemorating first/inaugural flight of Octave Chanute’s biplane glider on July 27, 1896, in Chicago, Illinois, U.S.A., by one of Chanute’s associates with biplane glider; cancellation stamp dated July 27, 1984 in Chicago; includes information on reverse.
